title: What makes post-grunge different from grunge? What bands are considered post-grunge instead of just grunge? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think post-grunge is a pejorative term for bands (and their music) that were blatantly copying innovative and distinctive bands whose popularity had largely faded following the folding of Nirvana (the band most synonymous with the so-called genre). Not only are post-grunge ham-fistedly derivative and in original, but their sound is inferior to the bands they try to sound like. (They don't have the x-factor that the trendsetting bands had.) They also sound outdated, like products of a bygone era. (The trendsetting grunge bands channeled the pessimism and cynicism of the Pacific Northwest circa the early 90s.) Examples of post-grunge bands: Bush / Bush XCollective Soul (early)Theory of a DeadmanStaind

thing is, grunge is not really a genre rather than a scene, in that sense, unlike the punk /post-punk music, which are clearly two separeted genres stylistically. Plus, grunge became a trend in it’s time, so in reality every band that played “grunge like” and surfaced after the first original generation of grunge bands is post-grunge. But the post-grunge concept is not and aesthetic one but commercial, so every band that played “grunge” trying to capitalize on the early 90’s grunge trend could be labeled as post-grunge, as they were not “moving forward” the genre but were just rounded by music labels to make some buck. Nickelback, Creed, Foo Fighters, Matchbox Twenty are example of post-grunge bands, whose objective was clearly to make the “grunge sound” comercially acceptable by lowering on the angst and loudness.

‘Post’ anything is music that is influenced by something yet is different. REM was a ‘Post-Punk’ band. They were singer songwriters that used punk style licks and riffs throughout their music. Grunge was basically a rehash of Bad Brains more or less. Bad Brains took the music of the Sex Pistols and the Ramones and fused it with Black Sabbath (originally they were a fusion jazz band ironically). Grunge took this a step further and fleshed it out with more ‘complex’ songwriting.

I love the post grunge bands. I like grunge too but I like to see live music and there is only a handful of original grunge, grunge bands still touring. I don’t mind that they used grunge as their foundation. I think of it as inspiration and a natural progression of where music was going in the 90’s. Some of my favorites are: Seether 3 Days Grace Puddle of Mudd Godsmack Stone Temple Pilots Collective Soul Live Incubus Flyleaf Bush Smashing Pumpkins
